Juan tells the Kiva lenders to support agriculture more and to keep the borrowers in mind, especially when they are ready for an increase.

He will now use his new Kiva loan to buy organic products and nuc hives because selling his honey is guaranteed.  He will also buy merchandise for his wife to continue expanding her market. She has orders for women’s and children’s underwear.  He also plans to use his Kiva loan to repair the floors in his house.  He is happy to be able to provide for his and his family’s well-being every day.

loans.use: buy organic products, nuc hives, children's clothing and underwear, and to make home repairs.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with two children, bothl of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past year, she has operated a clothes (Leso's) selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of competition from other clothes sellers in the market. She dreams of establishing a bigger shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase bundles of leso's for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of leso's for resale.

loans.name: Jesukpego Group

texts.fr:
JESUKPEGO est un groupement constitué de treize personnes et dont la présidente(celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) se nomme Cécile. Les membres du groupe vivent dans le même village.Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupement sollicite pour la deuxième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Cécile est âgée de 37ans et vit au Bénin. Cécile ne vit plus avec son mari, mais seule avec ses trois enfants. Tous ses enfants sont scolarisés. Cécile a très peu fréquenté l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Cécile  mène comme activité la vente des poulets, des canards et des escargots. A côté de cette activité, Cécile vend des vêtements. Cécile exerce cette activité il y a une dizaine d’année environ, ce qui lui permet  d’assurer les diverses charges de la famille. Cécile s’approvisionne dans l’une des villes du Bénin. Ce deuxième prêt permettra certainement à Cécile et aux autres membres du groupement JESUKPEGO de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
.
texts.en:
JESUKPEGO is a group consisting of 30 people and whose president (the one who has the raised hand in the photo) is named Cécile. The members of the group live in the same village. To increase their working capital, the group seeks, for the second time, a loan from ALIDé. 

Cécile is 37-years-old and lives in Bénin. Cécile no longer lives with her husband but only with her three children. All of her children are in school. Cécile has very little schooling. In order to meet her needs and those of her children, Cécile conducts the business of selling chickens, ducks and snails. Alongside this activity, Cécile sells clothing. Cécile has been in this business for around ten years, enabling her to provide for the various family expenses. Cécile stocks up in one of the towns of Bénin. 

This second loan will certainly allow Cécile and the other members of the JESUKPEGO group to raise the level of their activity and to increase their customer base and their income.

loans.use: to buy chickens, ducks and clothing

loans.name: Leyli

texts.es: Leily de 52 años, es una mujer alegre y dinámica, convive con su pareja y es madre de dos hijos, de 15 y 13 años, a quienes desea darles una buena educación y alimentación. El trabajo al que se dedica es la venta de pescado, este trabajo lo realiza en un pequeño mercado de su ciudad. Tiene diez años realizando esta actividad, de los tiene siente años en este mismo mercado. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que trabaja a medio tiempo,  es decir por las mañana vende y por las tardes se dedica a sus hijos para ayudarlos con las tareas del colegio. Este será el segundo crédito con MFP, por tanto espera el apoyo de cada uno de ustedes para continaur desarrollando su negocio. Con el monto solicitado, comprará materiales de pesca, pues tiene en mente salir ella misma a pescar para no tener que pagar inetermediarios que le porveen el pescado.
texts.en: Leily, 52, is a cheerful, dynamic woman who lives with her common-law husband and two children, ages 15 and 13.  She wants to provide them with good food and a proper education.  Her business is selling fish in the small city market.  She has been in this activity for ten years, seven of which have been in this same market.  What she enjoys most about her work is the fact that it is part time only.  She works in the morning and helps her children with their homework in the afternoons.  This is her second loan through MFP and she counts on your help so she can keep working.  She plans to use the loan to buy fishing supplies so she can go out fishing on her own and not have to pay the intermediary suppliers.

loans.use: To buy fishing supplies.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a taxi driver who greatly contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. Sophia has a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for the children. 

Sophia has operated a water-selling business for the past year, selling from home and going door-to-door to her neighbours. In addition, she also owns a cereals shop, where she earns her other source of income. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation in the business. She dreams of establishing a water-selling shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, Sophia wants to purchase a water tank. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase a water tank.

loans.name: Nkioriais

texts.en:
Nkioriais is 41 years old, married, and together they have three children. He has been a farmer for the past six years.  He has been a good client. He paid his previous loan well, and this is his third loan from KADET LTD, which he will use to buy farm supplies.

With the profits generated he plans to pay school fees for his children. He dreams of being a prominent farmer. He is an assiduous man who works with effort to attain more despite limited resources.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel works hard to support her family. She is married and has a frozen foods business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more frozen foods to sell. She has been in this business for four years.

In the future, Raquel would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more frozen foods to sell.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en: Aged 62, Stephen is a Ugandan male with 9 children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. Stephen is a banana farmer who dreams of building a permanent house for his family to replace their grass-thatched house. In the future, he would like to venture into animal sales to increase his income. Stephen is requesting this loan to buy goats to sell ahead of the Christmas season when demand is high.

loans.use: to buy goats for resale.

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Mrs. Sum is a 46-year-old married woman, the loving mother of nine children, and is in the business of growing vegetables for sale. She works on her own farmland that is next to her house, earning approximately $2.00 per day. This income cannot support the family well. Two of her sons also work hard to support the family, especially their small brothers and sisters who are school aged. Sum feels pity for her two sons who always go to work by taking a motor taxi and sometimes by walking. It’s really difficult for them and they have to spend much money as well. Therefore, Sum decided to ask for some funds from HKL and Kiva in the sums of $1,200 to buy a motorcycle for her sons for travelling to work. In the future, she wishes to send some of her children to join the university.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for her sons for travelling to work.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 30 years old.  She is single and blessed with two children. She sells clothes in the area of Mathare and she has a good customer base. She has been in this business for the last three years and earns an income of KES.10,000 per month.

Jacqueline is applying for her first loan of KES.15,000 from KADET LTD which she plans to use to buy more clothes to sell.

She will use the anticipated profit to expand her business and start importing new clothes. In the future, Jacqueline hopes to set up a boutique.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Purity

texts.en: Purity is 35 years old and married to Dennis . She supports a family of eight with the help of her husband. She runs an M-PESA (branchless banking) business and a clothing boutique, which are doing well.  She has been in business for four years and earns a monthly income of KES 35,000. She has been given a loan of KES 70,000, which she used to purchase more clothes for sale.  The anticipated profits will be used to expand her business. Since this is her second loan, she hopes to repay it on time. She dreams of having a bright future.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for sale

loans.name: Getrudis

texts.es:
Getrudis cuenta con 39 años de edad, es viuda, tiene 3 hijos los cuales se encuentran estudiando el mayor estudia las prepa se llama Fernando y gabi teresa esta en la secundaria y el menor que se llama miguel ángel esta en el preescolar.

Ella es comerciante vende pan y empanadas tiene 15 años con el negocio e invertirá su préstamo en la compra de los insumos que utiliza como son: harina, manteca, azúcar, huevo, rollar, carbonato, pintura, etc. A doña getrudis le gustaría poner una panadería esta muy agradecida con su préstamo ya que le ayudo mucho.
texts.en:
Gertrudis, 39, is a widow.  She has three children attending school.  Her oldest is Fernando and is going to high school, Gabi Teresa is in secondary school and the youngest who is called Miguel Ángel is in Preschool.

She is a merchant selling bread and turnovers.  She’s been in business fifteen years and will use the loan to buy the ingredients she uses like: flour, shortening, sugar, eggs, baking powder, baking soda, food coloring, etc.  Gertrudis would like to open a bakery.  She is very grateful for the loan because it helped her a lot.

loans.use: to buy bread baking ingredients.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothes and shoes

loans.name: Rawan

texts.en:
Rawan is a 46-year-old married woman from Al Hussein, Amman; Jordan, and a mother of four children.

Rawan is making knitwear from her home. Rawan started her business using only one machine and now she is requesting a loan of 1500 JD to purchase a new knitwear machine since she started a partnership with a knitwear shop owner to provide him with her products according to a certain profit percentage.

Rawan is looking to open her own shop for knitwear products with an aspiration of purchasing her own car and home.

loans.use: to purchase a new knitwear machine.

loans.name: Parbati

texts.en:
Parbati is 36 years-old. She is married and has two children aged 17 and 8. In 2005, she established her grocery store business.  Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she supoorts her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buys grocery goods for her business.  In the future, Parbati plans to improve the economic conditions of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery store, called a pasal, is an important part of the local economy.  Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home.  Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margains.  By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability.  While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buys grocery goods

loans.name: Daniel Felipe

texts.es:
Daniel es un joven emprendedor que a pesar de su corta edad ya tiene experiencia en el manejo de su negocio, y gracias a su buena atención lo ha podido sacar adelante. Daniel tiene 19 años de edad y desde hace 2 años montó su negocio que es una venta y alquiler de productos para decoración de fiestas y banquetes. Daniel terminó su secundaria y debido a que sus padres son personas con muy bajos recursos económicos, se vio en la obligación de buscar un empleo para aportar económicamente en su hogar; como las oportunidades de empleo fueron muy pocas, Daniel decidió montar su propio negocio. Desde entonces, atiende su negocio todos los días y gracias a su buena atención y calidad de los productos que ofrece ha podido captar un gran número de clientes. Debido a que su negocio lo montó con muy bajo capital, aún le hacen falta algunos productos que requiere para ofrecer un servicio completo a sus clientes, es por esto que Daniel busca que un préstamo le brinde la oportunidad de acceder a la compra de vasos y copas de cristal, y a la compra de sillas las cuales pueda alquilar y vender en su negocio.
Daniel espera que de esta manera sus clientes queden más satisfechos con su servicio y de esta manera aumenten sus ventas considerablemente. Daniel sueña con tener una gran casa de banquetes donde pueda generar empleo para varias personas y desde la cual les pueda ofrecer a sus padres una mejor calidad de vida y mayores oportunidades económicas.

loans.use: Compra de vasos y copas de cristal, y a la compra de sillas las cuales pueda alquilar y vender en su negocio.

loans.name: Benkadi Kagoua 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les  membres du groupe  Benkadi Kagoua 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles traditionnelles à Kouroubadougou, un des villages de San, 4ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est  l’arachide  avec   DJENEBA, 1 ere assise de la droite vers la gauche, sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte  acheter des intrants, semence, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de labour  pour l’exploitation de 1 hectare. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village et au marché de San, après la récolte, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 165.000 FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi Kagoua 1 group are married women with an average age of 40, with 4 children and all living in traditional families in Kouroubadougou, one of the villages in San, the fourth largest administrative region of Mali. They work with Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to succeed in their agricultural business during the winter period.
They are on their third loan with the institution; previous loans have been fully repaid. The crop grown is peanut - under the responsibility of DJENEBA, seated on the far right in the photo.
With her loan, she plans to buy inputs, seed, small agricultural equipment and to pay the labour costs for the 1 hectare farm. The production will be sold in the village and in San market, following the harvest, to a mixed customer base of both men and women.
She plans to generate an average profit of 165,000FCFA per harvest. This profit will allow her to repay her loan and also to assist her husband with the daily expenses.

loans.use: to buy agricultural inputs, seed, small agricultural equipment, and to pay labour costs.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 24 years old, not married, and from Iringa District. She is a mother of one child. Agnes used to volunteer herself at secondary school that is near her ward, in order to impact some knowledge to students about life skills. 

She has also employed herself by selling house ware items such as cups, plates and spoons. The business helps her to provide basic needs to both her mother and her daughter.  She is requesting a loan from Kiva to expand and increase the scale of her business by buying varieties of home products.

loans.use: to expand her business by purchasing home products.

loans.name: Ndioutha's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe fait partie du banc villageois qui a été crée le  15 octobre 2015. Il est composé de femmes du même village. Une bonne ambiance anime les réunions de groupe parce que les membres sont solidaires et s'activent principalement dans le commerce. 
GNILANE debout à droite de la photo et levant la main est âgée de 48 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 8 enfants dont 3 garçons et 5 filles. Elle s'active dans le commerce d'huile dans son village.
Ave le prêt reçu, elle se rend dans les marchés hebdomadaires pour  acheter 5 bouteilles d'huile de 20 litres chacune à 16 000 FCFA l’unité. Ensuite elle les revend dans son village à 18500 FCFA l'une. 
Les bénéfices récoltés de cette activité vont permettre d'une part à épargner au niveau du banc villageois et d'autre part à participer à la dépense quotidienne pour aider son mari en achetant la nourriture pour la famille.
texts.en:
This group is part of a 'banc villageois' that was created on October 15, 2015. It is made up of women from the same village. The meetings have a good ambiance because the members are united and are primarily businesswomen.

Gnilane is standing on the right side of the photo with her hand raised. She is 48 years old. She is married and has eight children, three boys and five girls. She sells oil in the village.

With this loan, she will go to the weekly markets to buy five 20-liter bottles of oil at 16,000 francs apiece. Then, she will resell them in the village at 18,500 francs apiece.

The profits received from the sales will allow her to save in the 'banc villageois' as well as assist with the daily expenses, aiding her husband with buying food for the family.

loans.use: to buy five bottles of oil.

loans.name: Ranaivomanana

texts.fr:
Ranaivomanana a  60 ans, il est marié. Le couple a cinq enfants dont 4 déjà mariés. Le dernier travaille déjà et ne vit plus chez lui. Sa femme l’appuie dans  son activité génératrice de revenu. 
Il a 5  années d’expérience dans l’activité de confection et de vente de draps. Avant, il travaillait auprès d’une unité de boulangerie et a créé une unité de pâtisserie. L’idée de créer cette activité lui est venue à l’esprit car sa sœur vendait des draps, Ayant constaté l’existence du marché et la rentabilité de l’activité, il a décidé de se lancer dans le secteur mais tout en confectionnant lui-même même les draps.  
Il projette de faire lui-même la broderie mais cela nécessite l’acquisition d’une machine à broder.

loans.use: acheter des toiles draps imprimés et unis

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.en:
For five years, I've been dedicated to the purchase of bed clothes, shoes, clothes to people and clients of offices that I visit. Thanks to my business I have been able to support my daughter, since I am unmarried mother. Christmas is approaching, so from November to December I need a loan in order to fill my inventory. This way I will have the variety needed to meet the needs of my customers!

SPANISH
Tengo cinco años de dedicarme a la compra de ropa de cama, zapatos, ropa en general y la vendo a personas y clientes de oficinas que visito, mis ventas las hago de contado y al credito. Gracias a mi negocio he podido mantener a mi hija, ya que soy madre soltera. En este momento se acerca la epoca de navidad en la que desde Noviembre comienzo a vender mas mercaderia, por lo que necesito tener variedad de producto y poder suplir las necesidades de mis clientes.

loans.use: Compra de juegos de ropa de cama, sartenes, zapatos, ropa de hombre y mujer.

loans.name: Komayor

texts.en: B. operates a small restaurant in her locality. She sells different kinds of local meals. Her customers' demand for more meals is on the increase everyday. She wants to cook in large quantity. She is seeking a loan of $950 from Kiva to enable her cook more meals to serve her customers.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Agnes would like to buy a water tank

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: "I am happy that Lift Above Poverty Organization has come to my rescue," says Mrs. Kate E..  Kate, who hails from Asaba, Delta State, Nigeria, sells bags of rice and provisions. She is 35 years of age and has five children. She is pleased with LAPO.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of rice & provisions

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr:
Mrs. Afi B., 41, is mother of six children. Coming from a poor family, she is responsible for many relatives—lots of mouths to feed but few resources. Her business is stocking and reselling gari (i.e., manioc flour, a Togolese staple). This business is quite profitable and could be even more so if she were able to invest more capital into her micro-business. For this reason she is asking for a loan of US$ 800 so that she can stock a consistent amount of gari and thus increase her turnover and her profit.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Agée de 41 ans, Madame B. Afi est mère de six (6) enfants. Sortie d’une famille pauvre, elle a à sa charge beaucoup d’autres personnes de sa famille. Beaucoup de bouches à nourrir mais peu de ressources. Son activité est le stockage et la vente du gari. Ce commerce est bien rentable et peut l’être d’avantage si elle s’investit d’avantage. C’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite $800 pour faire un stockage consistant en vue d’accroître son chiffre d’affaire et son revenu.

loans.use: sale of gari (manioc flour, a Togolese staple food)

loans.name: Lulu Aulia

texts.en:
Lulu is a mother who is talented in sewing materials together in many different styles and patterns. She can also put a printed design on your dress if you want. Lulu is 50 years of age and has been doing her sewing business almost 30 years.

She is thankful for the opportunity to be able to have access to loans for improving her small business. She said that this is the first time she will be borrowing money and this money will buy her a brand new sewing machine.

She has six children, and she is not depending on anyone for money and support. She works six days of the week, and she gets 80 tala a day at this time.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine, paint and brushes for her sewing business

loans.name: Lasela

texts.en: Fourty four year old Lasela S. owns a small grocery shop in the village of Lotofaga Alasopo.  Her husband, like her, is also unemployed, but works on the small family taro plantation to earn extra income for their family.  She’s a new member to the program and has an existing shop, but has decided to join SPBD to get financial support for improving her business.  With their combined current income they are able to send their five children to school.  With this loan, she aims to buy more products to sell and extend her shop.  She hopes that any future success will allow her family to live more comfortably, as well as send her children to university.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Marsinah

texts.en: Marsinah is a 44-year-old woman. Before joining MBK, her husband, D., was the only one who worked in the family. But since joining MBK, she started her own business producing bamboo matting at her house. She usually earns about US$ 23 per month. She is requesting a loan of US$ 150 to expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Expansion of her bamboo mat business

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
"I have lived all my life in a small town called Arifwala in Pakistan. I am the mother of four: three boys and one girl. Two of my sons operate their business in the food market and transport various items on order from different traders, while the younger two study at a local school.

I am borrowing for the second time from Asasah, a microfinance institution. This time we require a loan for our wheat business which my husband operates in the grain market. I raise cows at home and sell milk.

I have four other women in my loan group who are also in need of loans. Zainab B. wants to pay off the remaining money owed for their cow. Khalida B. will use the loan to expand their snacks stall. Shahnaz B. wants a loan to repair their family's rickshaw. Shamim B. requires loan for her son’s embroidery business."

loans.use: Expand their wheat business

loans.name: Ndeye Fatou

texts.fr:
Madame Ndèye Fatou P. born in 1962 and married, is a member of the Khodoba Village Bank since 6 and a half years. Since joining Khodoba's microfinance program, she has never had a problem respecting her loan repayments and commitments. Madame P. wishes to expand and promote her business selling fruits and vegetables (such as cabbage, sorrel, aubergine, gombo, oranges, tangerines, mangoes, etc.). Hence, she is requesting her 8th loan for a term of 6 months with one bulk reimbursement payment at the end.

Mme Ndèye Fatou P., mariée, née le 30/07/1962 est membre du Banc villageois de Khodoba, six ans et demi. Depuis son entrée dans le Programme de Microfinance, Mme P. n'a jamaais eu de problème pour honorer ses engagements. Elle souhaite promouvoir son commerce de fruits et légumes (choux, oseille, aubergine, gombo, orange, mandarine, mangue, etc.). C'est pour cela qu'elle sollicite ce 8ème prêt qu'elle propose de rembourser au bout de 6 mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: To purchase goods for resale

loans.name: Sandra Victoria

texts.es:
Mrs. Sandra makes a living selling various products out of her home located in the municipality of Villanueva, where she has been a resident for several years.

She is a mother of two children to whom she has the responsibility of maintaining, educating and providing a good roof over their heads. She currently in need of financial help with the acquisition of products for her store. This is the reason for her request to Ceprodel for a timely loan which will enable her to obtain the products that she will later sell in her store.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

La actividad económica a la que se dedica la señora Sandra es a la venta de productos varios en su casa de habitación ubicada en el municipio de Villanueva del cual ella es originaria desde hace varios años.

Es madre de dos hijos que tiene la responsabilidad de mantener dándole estudios, alimentación y un techo digno donde vivir. La necesidad que actualmente atraviesa es la adquisición de recursos económicos para adquirir los productos de la pulpería. Por este motivo acude a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito oportuno y así adquirir los productos para luego comercializarlos en su pulpería.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise.

loans.name: Irene

texts.es:
Irene works hard daily to take care of her family and she decided to obtain small animals, for awhile she has been involved in raising bulls and cows and she has established her own modest stable. She desires to acquire a cow to increase her production of milk and therefore her income and wellbeing of the family.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Irene, se esfuerza a diario para lograr el sustento diario D. su familia y decidió obtenerlos a través D. la crianza D. pequeños animalitos, hace mucho también decidió incursionar en la crianza D. toros y vacas y poco a poco estableció su pequeño y modesto establo.Desea adquirir una vaquita más para incrementar su producción D. leche y con ella sus ganacias y bienestar D. su familia.

loans.use: To purchase a little cow.

loans.name: Meme

texts.en: S. is married to a driver who earns a meager income that is insufficient to meet family expenses.  The family also grows vegetables, and tends a small rice field.  When S. heard about The Kiva program, she approached SMT and requested a loan of Le.1,000,000 to increase her family's farm production for sale and consumption.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and  fertilizer, and to hire laborers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of inverter parts and other materials for a small inverters repair shop.

loans.name: Theresia

texts.en:
Theresia is a widow with 4 children (ages 23, 20, 18 and 10). She started her food-selling business in 2007. Each day, she works from 7:00 am to 6:00 pm at her business. As a result, she is able to generate a monthly profit of approximately $250 from her sales.

Theresia is now seeking a loan to buy more food items such as rice and millet for her business.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional food items (e.g., rice and millet) to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Yaguarón, distante a 15 Km de la Oficina de Paraguarí, se reunieron unas mujeres con ganas de emprender actividades productivas y otras para aumentar su capital de trabajo con el fin de mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia, de ahí que se pusieron en contacto con nosotros para interiorizarse sobre el programa, quienes aceptaron por la oportunidad que se les está ofreciendo ya que ninguna otra institución lo ha hecho.

Este grupo esta conformado por mujeres con distintas actividades que le generan ingresos para sus familias. Gilda P. es modista y posee muchas clientas que van a su casa solicitando la confección de vestidos y uniformes para sus oficinas; las señoras Isabel, Francisca, Bernardita, Leoncia y Edith poseen cantinas en distintas escuelas y colegios en donde venden principalmente comidas rápidas, golosinas y gaseosas.

Basílica S. y Graciela O. poseen una despensa cada una, en donde comercializan todo tipo de mercaderías. Reina Q. Amalia Saldívar y Patricia V. se dedican a la venta de distintos tipos de frutas y verduras. Florentina es artesana y se dedica a la costura de telas típicas de nuestro país.

Emilce Gonzáles y Amelia F. tiene un kiosco, Felicita C. es vendedora ambulante de diversos tipos de mercaderías. Gilda Martínez es empleada doméstica y está deseosa de poder comprar mercaderías varias para vender y así incrementar sus ingresos. Por último tenemos a Cándida V. que se dedica a la venta de una de las comidas típicas más consumidas en nuestro país y que se llama Chipa.

El comité lleva por nombre Renacer, quienes actualmente se encuentran en el cuarto ciclo, con calificación excelente, integrada por 17 emprendedoras y activas mujeres.
texts.en:
15 km from the Office of Paraguiri, in the city of Yaguarón, a group of women who wanted to start businesses joined together so that they could increase their working capital, and thus improve their quality of life and that of their families. The women contacted Fundación Paraguaya in order to learn about its program, and when Fundación Paraguaya offered them an opportunity they accepted it, since no other institution had already made them an offer. The group is made up of women who work in different productive activities that allow them to generate income for their families. Gilda P. is a dressmaker and has many customers who go to her house to order suits and uniforms for their jobs. Isabel, Francisca, Bernadita, Leoncia, and Edith run refectories in different schools, where they mainly sell fast food, candy, and soft drinks. Basílica S. and Graciela O. each have a grocery store where they sell all kinds of merchandise. Reina Q., Amalia Saldívar and Patricia V. make a living selling various fruits and vegetables. Florentina is a craftswoman and makes a living weaving traditional Paraguayan fabrics. Emilce Gonzáles and Amelia F. have a kiosk, while Felicita C. is a street vendor who sells a variety of merchandise. Gilda Martínez works as a domestic servant and wants to buy a variety of merchandise so she can sell it and thus increase her income. Finally, we have Cándida V., who makes a living selling Chipa, which is one of the most popular traditional foods in Paraguay. The name of this group is Renacer, and it is made up of 17 active and enterprising women. They are currently in their fourth loan cycle and have an excellent rating.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Your loans will be invested in each of their respective activities, such as purchasing fabric, candy, cornstarch, lard, meat, beverages, baked goods, oil, noodles, sugar, rice, flour, dairy products, various fruits and vegetables, etc.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 32 year old mother of one school-going child. She lives with her family in Nyalenda Kisumu in Kenya. She operated a dressmaking shop in Nairobi until 2004 when she moved her business to Kisumu. She specializes in making women's dresses and school uniforms.

The central location of her shop in busy environment coupled with many years of doing good business within the community, has gained her a good reputation and a wide customer base. She intends to acquire additional stock of dressmaking materials with a portion of $500 for which she has applied.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of dressmaking materials.

loans.name: Say

texts.en: Say N., 40, is a widowed farmer who lives with two of her children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. She typically makes about US$4 each day from growing rice and many kinds of vegetables and is financially aided by two of her children who work in garment factory. Say would like to take out a loan of US$400 to purchase bean seeds and to hire farm workers to plow her farmland.

loans.use: Say would like to purchase bean seeds and hire workers for her farm.

loans.name: Vumilia I.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Vumilia M. from Mbeya. She is a widow with no children. She is responsible for supporting 2 dependents because they are orphans.

Vumilia has been running a genge business since 2002. Her business is buying tomatoes, rice, and fish and selling them at higher prices. She works at the business for 4 hours per day, 3 days per week. Currently she earns about $100 from her business.

She is requesting a loan of $425 in order to buy more rice, fish, and tomatoes in bulk. In the future, she plans to establish another business. Vumilia thanks you for your support!

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy more rice, fish, and tomatoes in bulk

loans.name: Seema Manzoor Hussain Group

texts.en:
Seema baji is 46 years old and has lived in Lahore, Pakistan for her entire life. Her husband is named M. H. and he works in a factory. She is the mother of five children: four sons and one daughter. Her first two sons work in a factory. The other two are enrolled in a local school. Her daughter is 20 years old and stays at home to help with household work. Seema baji runs a grocery store which she opened at her house. She started this business because her husband’s income is insufficient to meet household expenses and the cost of her children’s education. She has been in this line of work for three years, and has repaid a previous loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a new loan to buy groceries for her shop. 

She leads a group with several other members who live nearby. Rani baji and Musarat baji each want a loan to repair their auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Sanobar baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Rashidan baji wants a loan to buy a flour polisher to resell. Sabiha naz baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her store. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop and other items

loans.name: Aminadab

texts.en:
Greetings from Aminadab R. in Rwamagana, in the Eastern province! Aminadab is 26 years old, married with 2 children.

Aminadab started up a business in 2007. He runs a shop selling various kinds of shoes and women's clothes. He needs a loan of 500,000 Rwf, which will be used to expand his business. This loan will be repaid in 12 months on a monthly basis.

This entrepreneur believes that once he gets this loan, his shop will become bigger because he is planning to buy men’s clothes, which are more desirable in the market.

loans.use: to expand his business by beginning to sell men's clothing

loans.name: Kantutas Group

texts.es:
La asociación kantutas pertenece al centro focal Cascada ubicada en la ciudad de El Alto, hace un año que trabajan junto a la familia de Pro – Mujer.
La mayoría casadas y con familias numerosas, necesitan recursos económicos, para cubrir ciertas necesidades como ser guardapolvos y material escolar, ya que empieza un nuevo año escolar. Por este motivo  necesitan de mayores créditos para ampliar sus ventas con la seguridad de obtener mayores ingresos.
La asociación Kantutas se dedica al comercio en general, diversos productos son vendidos en puestos de mercados y calles de la ciudad, otras también tiene tiendas de barrio.
texts.en:
The Kantutas Association is in the Cascada center of the city of El Alto. They have been working for one year with the Pro-Mujer family. Most are married with large families, in need of economic resources to cover certain necessities such as school uniforms and supplies, since a new school year is starting. This is why they need large loans to increase their sales and to have the security of a larger income. The Kantutas Association are all in general business, selling various products in market stands and on the streets of the city. Some also have neighborhood shops.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: They need loans to increase their sales

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en: Chhem U., 39, is a local poultry seller, as well as a distiller of Khmer wine which she also sells. She has been running these businesses since 2000, and currently earning approximately $3 per day. She is married to Mr. Sharon, 44, who earns a daily income by selling firewood. Chhem U.'s husband has always collected the firewood from a people that cut trees in the forest and he stocks supplies of firewood for resale. The couple has four children who are students. Chhem U. is asking for a $1000 loan to buy additional poultry to raise and use the remainer of the loan for her husband to expand his firewood business.

loans.use: To buy some poultry to raise

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is 39 years old and married with three children. He sells provisions and drinks. Joseph lives in Ubiaja Edo State, Nigeria. He needs a loan of N100000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. He says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and provisions to sell

loans.name: Nguen Thi

texts.en:
Nguen Thi M’ai, 39 years old, started with TYM Fund in 2000. She and her husband have four children, ages 3, 14, 16 and 19 years old. With the help of TYM, all the children are able to go to school.

The story of the M’ai family begins in 2000. With a TYM loan of 700 VND ($40) , Mrs. M’ai bought some chickens and expanded her business. With the increased earnings, her husband was able to learn carpentry in Hanoi. Today, he and his wife own a successful carpentry business with 6 employees. Their income has increased from 1 million VND to 7 million VND per month ($395).

With the next loan of 20 million VND, Mrs. M’ai wants to invest in buying pigs and Mr. M’ai wants to buy some new wood. If everything works out well, maybe Mr. M’ai could even buy a new motorbike next year. This is a wish he has had for a long time and which would have been inconceivable for him 10 years ago.

loans.use: Buying pigs

loans.name: Afia

texts.en:
Afia S., 47, is married to a photographer and has five children, three sons and two daughters. One is a teacher while the rest are in the senior high and the junior schools. She lives with the family in a rented apartment in the farming/commercial town of Achiase, near Akim Oda in the Eastern Region of Ghana. 

Afia trades in foodstuffs such as yams, procuring the tubers all the way from the northern part of the country and selling them from a store in the market to food vendors and other customers. Afia has been in business for three years and is requesting a loan to expand her business. She hopes to give her children the best of educations.

loans.use: To procure tubers of yam.

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en: Mambo (Greetings) from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Rukia R. from Mwanza. She is married with four children between the ages of 3 and 13 years old. Rukia has been running a tailoring business since 2005 making clothes for women. She works at the business for twelve hours per day, six days per week. She currently earns about $100 from her business. Rukia is requesting a loan of $400 in order to purchase machines and to renovate her building. In the future, she plans to have her own house. Rukia thanks you for your support! ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase machines and to renovate her building

loans.name: Rosalio

texts.es: Rosalio R. D. P. D. 48 años D. edad, resiD. en nueva San Salvador junto a su compañera D. vida y sus tres hijos menores D. edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. El trabaja como taxista y posee su propio vehículo, es una persona muy respetuosa, el cual se preocupa por brindar un buen servicio a sus clientes, es por eso que cada año Rosalio le da un mantenimiento completo a su taxi D. manera que su servicio sea más seguro. Por lo anterior es que Rosalio solicita un préstamo, con el fin D. comprar nuevas piezas a su automóvil.
texts.en:
Rosalio R. D. P. is 48 years old, and lives in Nueva San Salvador with his wife and their three young children, who are in school. He works as a taxi driver and owns his own vehicle. Rosalio is a very respectful man who makes sure that he provides good service to his customers. Rosalio performs complete maintenance on his taxi every year so that his taxi service will be safer. It is for this reason that Rosalio is asking for a loan, which he will use to purchase new parts for his automobile.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Furkat

texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following its inception, MLF “MicroInvest” became a Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. In October, 2008, MLF “MicroInvest”, together with LLC ‘Frontiers”, founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”.

“Arvand”, being an assignee of “MicroInvest”, continues to carry out the mission to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Furkat U. was born in 1982 in the Istaravshan region of Tajikistan. Furkat has a specialized education, but because of the low salary he has to be involved in another business. He is married. Furkat is engaged in commercial service and trade, so he trades sweets in the local bazaar in Istaravshan. Furkat has traded chocolates, cakes, and other sweets for 15 years. His mother helps him during the weekend. Furkat is applying to KIVA with the request of business development loan of 1600 STJ to purchase new goods of a greater assortment. Furkat buys sweets in Khukand 2 times per week. There is additional family income from the sale of traditional dresses. Furkat thanks KIVA for its support.

loans.use: To purchase new goods of a greater assortment.

loans.name: God's Devine Favor Group

texts.en: Oliver is the father of three children; the youngest is just 3 months old. He deals in petroleum products (gasoline) along with scratch cards being sold by GSM Companies in Liberia, and he has been in the business for the last five years. He buys the product wholesale and sells it at retail prices. He sees the shortage of customers as his greatest challenge. "The secret to my success in this business is buying more products to get more profit," he says. He dreams of going back to school to continue his education and also to take care of his children.

loans.use: To purchase wholesale drums of gasoline for retail sales

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn A. has a shop in Abura where she sells cosmetics and other items. Evelyn has received a junior high school education. She is married and has no children. Her husband is a mason. Evelyn has been selling cosmetics since 2004. She is responsible for paying bills. Her loan will be used to to buy more cosmetics to sell. She hopes to reinvest the new profits from her business.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics for resale.

loans.name: Taulagia

texts.en:
Taulagia T. (0) is a 71-year-old woman living in the town of Saanapu Uta. She is widowed and has ten adult children.

Taulagia owns and operates a business raising crops, primarily planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 350 WST a month.

In 2002, Taulagia joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 3,150 WST which will be used to purchase harvesting equipment. The loan will be her 5th from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase harvesting equipment

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: fatou D. est commercante specialisee dans la vente de tissus depuis plus de sept ans.elle aide beaucoup son mari dans l'entretien de la famille.compte tenu de l'accroissement de la demande ses marches s'elargissent de jour en jour.par consequent elle sollicite un credit de cent mille(100 000)frs pour augmenter ses fonds.

loans.use: commerce

loans.name: Willy

texts.es:
Willy  vive en la calle Luis Espinal  de la zona Rio Seco en la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Vive en casa Propia, su familia vive en el interior del país. 

Trabaja como artesano en la reparación de calzados en su pequeño kiosco ubicado en la misma zona.
 
 El crédito lo destinará para la adquisición de una maquina de costura para cuero y así mejorar la atención de sus clientes, por lo tanto sus ingresos.
 
Es el primer  crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.
texts.en:
Willy lives on Luis Espinal Street in the district of Rio Seco in the city of El Alto. He lives in his own home with his family in the countryside.

He works as a cobbler repairing shoes from his small kiosk located in the same area. His loan will be used to acquire a sewing machine for leather so that he can improve the service he provides to his customers and increase his income.

This is Willy’s first loan with IMPRO. His evaluation indicates he is qualified for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a machine for sewing leather

loans.name: Levi

texts.en:
Levi G. is currently in the business of selling cold and soft drinks and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of  soda to sell.  Levi is 29 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a resturant. 

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more crates of soda to sell

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica B. sells clothes in Elmina. Veronica has received a senior high education.  She is married and has one child. Her husband is a fisherman. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and settlement of their apartment. Her loan will be used to buy shoes and clothes to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her expanded business to save to build a house.

loans.use: To buy shoes and clothes to sell.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali has been working as a farmer since 2003 and has 15 years of experience in this field. He is a 47-year-old married man and has ten children. Today, Ali is asking for a loan of $1,200 to purchase additional agricultural equipment in order to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase additional agricultural equipment

loans.name: Karta Ariana Group

texts.en:
Zalega is the group leader of the Karta Ariana 5 group. There are four members in this group.  They live in district 15 in Kabul Afghanistan. Zalega is the group leader.  She is 45 years old and she has four children, three daughters and one son. All her children are in school. Zalega wants to take a loan for the bakery she operates from her house. She needs wood for her bakery.

Mahfoz and Mohammad Sader want to take a loan for their fresh fruit selling business. They want to expand their business. 

Shakyllah wants to take a loan for the tailoring business she runs from her house. She wants to buy three new sewing machines. 

They have requested a group loan of 30000 Afghani.  They would like to say thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To improve and expand their businesses

loans.name: Candida Rosa

texts.es: Candida tiene 3 hijos, una mayor de edad, y 2 que tiene a cargo, el mayor trabaja como pintor, el otro hijo estudia 3 er  año de educación secundaria, y la hija menor estudia 3 er año de educación secundaria, trabaja para el Ministerio de educación  como docente primaria desde hace 15 años,  está solicitando su 7mo credito para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda, como es cambirle el zinc a la casa que se encuentra en mal estado y con las lluvias se le mojan algunas cosas,  es importante mencionar con los creditos anteriores otorgados por AFODENIC a mejorado su vivienda y ha mejorado sus condiciones de vida,  es una mujer que sueña con tener un porvenir mejor y que sus hijos tengan siempre lo basico y que estudien para que lleguen hacer excelentes profesionales, trabajo y sobre todo estar bien con Dios, profesan la religión evengélica.
texts.en:
Candida has three children, one an adult, and two under her care. The eldest is a painter, the other son is in 9th grade, and the youngest daughter is in third grade. She has been employed by the Ministry of Education as an elementary school teacher for the last 15 years. This is her 7th loan request which will be used for home improvements, specifically to replace the zinc metal sheeting on the roof which is in such bad state, that during the rainy season much of her belongings are water damaged. It bears mentioning that with her previous loans from AFODENIC she has improved her home and her living conditions. She is a woman who dreams with having a better future, that her children always have their basic needs met, that they study to become excellent professionals, that she have work, and above all, to be in good standing with God; they profess the evangelical faith.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To replace the roof.

loans.name: Vero

texts.en:
Vero sells garri (cassava flakes) at retail prices to her customers in the market. Vero is a widow and has four children. Her children are still dependent upon her and go to school. 

Vero is a hardworking woman and hopes for a bigger stall in the future. She is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more garri to sell. 

She is a committed LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more garri (cassava flakes) to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria A., age 31, manages a small rice field in Santa Josefa, Agusan del Sur. She has two children, the eldest of whom is only one year old. To continue to work on the farm, she really needs additional capital. Farming is not easy; you need hard work and money to achieve your desired harvest. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to increase her harvest. When her business is well established, she dreams of buying more land to help her relatives.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Pablo

texts.es:
el señor Pablo E. Nuñez tiene tiene 66 años de edad, vive en la aldea el Caimito. Pablo se dedica a la venta de refrescos en varios tamaños, agua en botes y bolsas.
tiene poco tiempo de vender dicho producto, en donde el vive es un lugar muy caliente, muchas personas van a su casa a comprar refrescos y agua.
el tambien se dedica a la fabricacion de lasos y hamacas, ahorita tiene varios pedidos de hamacas y necesita comprar el material para fabricarlas ya que no tiene capital para hacerlo.
con este pedido el va a tener buenas ganancias.
esta es su unica fuente de ingresos, Pablo es una persona de edad la cual no puede hacer otro tipo de actividad para ganarse la vida.
texts.en:
Pablo E. Nuñez is 66 years old and lives in the village of Caimito. Pablo sells soft drinks in various sizes and water in bottles and bags. He has little time to sell these products; the place where he lives is very hot and a lot of people come to his house to buy soft drinks and water. He also makes ropes and hammocks; he has several orders for hammocks and he needs to buy the material to make them but he doesn't have the capital to do so. With this order he will earn a lot. This is his only source of income; Pablo is an older person who cannot do other activities to make a living.

Translated from Spanish by Cara Gutterman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of soft drinks in various sizes; water in bottles and bags. Purchase of thread, hemp, and string.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.es:
Nelly se dedica a la confección de polleras y este producto lo vende en las ferias y también deja al crédito en las tiendas.
 
Vive en el callejon 2, Zona Santiago I de la ciudad de El Alto.
 
Su esposo trabaja como maestro de albañil y trabaja en distintas zonas en la ciudad de La Paz.
 
 Tiene dos  hijos  los cuales  se encuentran en edad escolar.
 
El crédito lo destinará a la compra de  material de construcción, con lo cual hará levantar una habitación donde pueda vivir ella y su familia. 
 
Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Nelly makes skirts and sells them at the fairs. She also leaves them on credit at stores. She lives at Callejon 2 in the Santiago I area in the city of El Alto. Her husband works as a master bricklayer in different areas of the city of La Paz. She has two school-age children. The loan is to buy construction material to raise a room where she and her family can live. It is her first loan from Impro. The completed evaluation qualifies her for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bricks, cement, and stucco to build a room

loans.name: Fe Y Amor 5 Group

texts.en:
Carmelina is the coordinator of her group Fe y Amor (Faith and Love), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the slums surrounding Santiago, a city famous for its production of tobacco and beef, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. As a single mother with her two children, she makes her home here in a simple structure.

Carmelina is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and having the opportunity to expand her business with low interest capital. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a beauty salon by purchasing a power generator. As you can imagine, this will be a large improvement in her beauty salon which is in an area where blackouts are common. She will use the profits to invest in her children's future by enrolling them in a private high school. Her long term goal is to save enough money to own her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: a power generator

loans.name: Alzira Salvador

texts.pt:
Alzira Salvador S. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província do mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, tem 38 anos de idade casada e mãe de 6 filhos de 18, 16, 14, 11, 8 e 4 anos de idade, os 5 mais velhos vão a escola. Fez somente 5ª classe, não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras por parte dos progenitores. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Sai de Maputo para Boane em 1991 quando se juntou ao seu marido, local onde residem até hoje. Tem um negócio próprio há mais de 18 anos, não possui nenhum empregado, trabalha cerca de 10 horas de tempo todos os dias. O seu marido também é negociante e ajuda nas despesas familiares. Alizira consegue um rendimento de cerca de 5.500.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua casa para responder necessidades prévias que possam surgir.
Já teve empréstimos na cooperativa de crédito TCHUMA mais tarde decidiu não continuar devido a varias motivos. Conheceu a Hluvuku um dia quando passava perto da instituição, tendo entrado e se informar das modalidades. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (Capulanas) para aumentar a quantidade e diversificar ainda mais o seu produto. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 13.000.00mt e 18.000.00mt, ambos para a mesma actividade.
 Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. O seu maior projecto é construir casas tipo dependências para aluguer, no futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para aplicar ainda mais no comércio.
texts.en:
Alzira Salvador S. was born in the city of Maputo, in the province of the same name in the south of Mozambique. She is 38 years old, married, and is the mother of 6 children who are 18, 16, 14, 11, 8 and 4 years old. The 5 older children attend school. Alzira only studied through 5th grade, and didn't continue because of her parents' lack of financial resources. She lives with her family in their own home, and apart from her children she isn't responsible for supporting anyone else financially. Alzira left Maputo for Boane in 1991 to join her husband, and they still live there today. She has had her own business for more than 18 years and does not have any other employees. She works around 10 hours every day. Her husband is also a business owner and helps to pay the household expenses. Alizira earns approximately 5500.00 Meticales each month, which go towards paying the household expenses. She also saves some money at home in order to cover any unforeseen needs. Alzira had previously taken out loans with the credit cooperative TCHUMA but later decided not to continue for various reasons. She found out about Hluvuku [the Kiva Field Partner] one day when she was passing by the Institution, as she entered and found out about the options available there. This is her 3rd loan, for the amount of 25,000.00 Meticales. She will use this money to buy capulanas [long pieces of fabric that have various uses] in order to increase and diversify the products she sells. Her earlier loans were for 13,000.00 Meticales e 18,000.00 Meticales, and both were used for the same purpose. She promises to repay the loan as indicated in order to be eligible for other loans later. Her main project is the construction of small houses to rent out. In the future she would like to apply for more loans to put towards her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of capulanas

loans.name: Non

texts.en:
Mrs. Non S. is 37 years old and she lives in Kdei Tnaot village in the Takeo Province. She breeds pigs at home and her husband, Mr. Yeng Chhoem, is a farmer who owns 2 hectares of land to cultivate rice for supporting his family. Aside from pig breeding, she is a palm juice collector who can earn some money for selling palm sugar. Through these activities, their living conditions are average, but they want to improve to a higher standard of living conditions. 

Mrs. Non S. decided to apply for a loan from AMK, a Kiva partner, to buy pig food and to build a pig stall for breeding pigs. This couple has three children, all of whom are attending a local public school.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Amy

texts.en:
Amy C. is from the village of Tag ibo Iligan City. She is 41 years old. Amy is married and has five school-aged children. Amy owns and operates a clothing store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling ready to wear items for both male and female customers in the local community. Amy has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Amy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Amy is requesting her first loan, for 5000 PHP, which will be used to expand the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand the business

loans.name: Jappo Liggey (Asf) N°10 Group

texts.fr:
Jappo Ligguey (asf)  est une association mixte composée de plusieurs personnes microentrepreuneuses. Elle a été créée en 2009 par un groupe de femmes pour  rassembler  tous leurs  paires  du  quartier  Angle Serigne Fallou  (asf) autour d’un même idéal  « l’entraide  pour travailler ». Elle est dirigée par Madame Marie N. D. et  est scindée en plusieurs sous groupes de 5 sous l’influence de l’agent de crédit de la caisse Moda Kane pour  que tous  les membres  puissent  bénéficier mieux des services d’U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que certains sous groupes ont déposé leur demande de crédit de 500 000 FCFA qu’ils vont se partager en part égale. 
Pour le sous groupe Jappo Liggey N°10, Madame Ndéye D. est la présidente. Elle est commerçante de fruits et chaussures depuis 30 ans en face de la gare routière pour se profiter de la plupart des clients qui emprunte très souvent le train pour le transport. Comme  les autres membres du sous groupe, Madame Ndéye D. souhaitait renouveler leur stock de marchandises avec le prêt octroyé.  Elle partage ce sous groupe avec Madame Astou N. qui vend des habits pour femme, Madame Amsatou N. commerçante de tissus, pagnes, ferr (perles) et colliers au niveau du marché Moussanté de Thiès, Madame Khady D. vendeuse de petits déjeuners et diner chez elle et de Madame Ndéye M. la trésorière qui vend des pagnes tissées, du petit déjeuner et diner dans sa kiosque qu’elle a installée à coté de chez elle.
texts.en:
Jappo Ligguey (asf) is a mixed association composed of several micro-entrepreneurial people.  It was created in 2009 by a group of women for gathering all their peers in the Angle Serigne Fallou (asf) district to focus on the same ideal:  mutual aid for work.  It is lead by Ms. Marie N. D. and is divided into several sub-groups of five. It is guided by the loan agent of the Moda Kane branch office, so that all the members may benefit more from U-IMCEC services.  And so, certain sub-groups have applied for a loan of 500,000 francs CFA that they will share equally with each other.  In sub-group Jappo Liggey N°10, Ms. Ndéye D. is the president.  She has been a merchant of fruit and vegetables for thirty years and is located opposite the bus station in order to take advantage of the bulk of customers who very often take the train.  Like the other members of the sub-group, Ms. Ndéye D. would want to replenish their stock of merchandise with the loan granted.  She shares in this sub-group with Ms. Astou N., who sells women's clothing;  Ms. Amsatou N., a merchant of fabrics, pagne cloth, ferr (pearls), and necklaces at the Moussanté market of Thiès;  Ms. Khady D., a breakfast and lunch vendor at her home; and Ms. Ndéye M., the treasurer, who sells woven pagne cloth and breakfast and dinner in a stall, which she set up next to her home.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Replenishing their inventories

loans.name: Yesebella Karen

texts.es:
Nuestra socia pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN INMACULADA CONCEPCIÓN”; Nuestra socia vive en el distrito de Anta provincia de Anta departamento de Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la  Sra. Yesebella,  ella tiene 23 años de edad, es soltera, Nuestra socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con la administración de su propia fotocopiadora y ti peos en un stand ubicado frente a la universidad particular Andina de Cusco, L a socia tiene alquilado un espacio para la venta de snack, Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de materiales de fotocopiadoras, comprará papeles A-4, tintas de colores y negro para la impresora y  papeles de tamaños diversos para los planos y gigantografías. Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para comprar tintes de impresión y papeles.

La socia agradece y valora el apoyo brindado mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Our member, Yesebella, 23 , is single and is a member of the “VIRGEN INMACULADA CONCEPCIÓN” communal bank; she lives in Anta district, Anta province, Cusco Department. Yesebella is single and she alternates her household chores with running her photocopy and typing service business in a stand located across from the private, Andina de Cusco, university. She also rents a space to sell snacks. She is asking for funds to buy photocopy supplies, A-4 size paper, color and black inks for the printer and paper in various sizes for plans and oversize photos. She asks for funds to buy paper and inks. She is grateful for and values the support offered through this means and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy printer ink and paper.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.es: Julia, de 52 años, es una madre de familia muy  trabajadora, es separada, y vive en su casa propia.Por las mañanas trabaja cuidando a una anciana,  y durante las  tardes, se dedica a la venta de  ropa  y  cosméticos de belleza. La modalidad de sus ventas las realiza  mediante pedidos, y sus  compradores son personas responsables en los  pagos, pues les brinda la mercadería a crédito. Julia está muy feliz con sus ventas, ya que le va muy bien en estos 8 años que lleva en el comercio. Inicialmente perdió su capital en este negocio,  por los créditos que brindó, y desde entonces, si tiene  clientes nuevos primero busca referencias para venderles con seguridad, o de lo contario les vende al contado. Su mayor anhelo es aumentar su capital  y después comprarse una vitrina donde pueda exhibir  su  mercadería.  Este es el  doceavo préstamo que tiene con MFP,  y seguirá siendo puntual con el pago de sus cuotas, pues desea tener nuevos créditos. En su grupo es un socia muy responsable y respetada.Tiene planeado invertir el dinero solicitado en la  compra de mercadería en ropa , para continuar progresando con  su negocio.
texts.en:
Julia, who is 52 years old, is a mother and very hardworking. She is separated and lives in her own house. In the mornings she takes care of an elderly woman. During the afternoons she sells clothing and cosmetics. She makes her sales through orders and her customers are people who are responsible in their payments—she sells merchandise to them on credit. Julia is very happy with her sales because they have been very good during the 8 years since she has had this business. At first she lost her capital in this business, because of the credit she extended to people. Since then, when she has new customers she first asks for references in order to sell to them with assurance, or she sells to them for cash up front. Her greatest wish is to increase her capital and then buy a vitrine where she can show her merchandise. This is the twelfth loan that she has had with Microfinanzas Prisma, and she will continue being punctual in her payments because she would like to have more loans in the future. In her group she is a very responsible and respected member. She plans to invest the requested money in buying clothing merchandise, so she can continue making progress with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: She will buy clothing merchandise to stock her business

loans.name: Petrona Del Carmen

texts.es:
la sra. Petrona del Carmen L. tiene varios años de dedicarse a este tipo de actividad, la cual la realiza en su casa de habitacion, tiene la ayuda de sus hijas para elaborar su producto.
las rosquillas las distribuye en diferentes negocios de la zona.
con los ingresos que le genera el negocio cubre los gastos en el hogar en un 100%  tiene tres hijas a su cargo y cursan la secundaria en centros  deducativos de la localidad,
a logrado sembrar maiz lo que le permite bajar los costos para elaborar su producto. 
gracias a las ganancias que le a brindado su negocio ella y su familia han mejorado las condiciones de vida. 
tiene a una de sus hijas estudiando en la universidad la cual es pasante de clases de administracion de empresas y una de sus ideas es que cuando ella se  gradue es apoyar a su madre en su pequeña fabrica mejorando el sistema de produccion y promocion de su productos.
texts.en:
Sra. Petrona del Carmen L. has been baking for several years. She works from home and makes her product with the help of her daughters. Her donuts are distributed to different businesses in the area. With the earnings from her business, Petrona is able to cover 100% of her household expenses. She has three daughters in her care who attend school in the area. Petrona also grows corn in order to lower some of her production costs.

Thanks to the income she has earned from her business, Petrona and her family have improved their living conditions. One of her daughters is studying business administration at the university and plans to support her mother after she graduates by opening a small factory to improve the production system and the marketing of her products.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase butter, flour, sugar, eggs, margarine, cheese, and firewood

loans.name: Anarkul's Group

texts.en: Anarkul S. is the leader of this group. She is 46, married, and her husband works as a teacher at the vocational school, receiving 2,500 soms per month. Anarkul has a kiosk where she sells convenience goods. She started this activity eight years ago with the initial investment of 300 soms and now she makes 2,000 soms per month. There are three children in their family: two sons and a daughter. The first son works in construction, the second son went to Russia to work to earn some money, and the daughter studies at school. When the daughter is free, she helps her mom in the kiosk. With money received from the loan, Anarkul wants to purchase a variety of goods: 20 kg of rigatoni, 10 kg of sugar, 20 bars of soap, 20 packs of juice, 3 blocks of cigarettes and 20 packs of powdered detergent. In the future she wants to expand her business and open a big store. Zarylkan E. is the treasurer of the group. She is 63 and a widow. Thirteen years ago, with the initial investment of 3,000 soms, she bought a calf and, since that moment, started to breed cattle. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase hay for her cattle. Mukaddas S., 40, is married. She makes and sells bread while her husband works as a taxi driver. Mukaddas started to sell bread eight years ago with the initial investment of 30,000 soms and now she makes 19,000 soms per month. There are four children in her family and all of them are students. If any of the family members has free time, he or she helps Mukaddas with her activity. With money received from the loan Mukkadas wants to purchase 50 bags of flour. In the future she plans to build a big house for her children. Dinara D., 21, is married and her husband works as a driver earning 2,500 soms per month. Dinara applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase a washing machine for her mom. Roza O., 53, is a widow. She has two sons: the older son is a bus driver and the second son is a student. Roza works as a nurse and earns 6,000 soms per month. She also breeds cattle, which she has been doing for thirty years. She now she wants to obtain a loan to purchase a calf and hay for her cattle. In the future she wants to save some money to contribute to her son’s wedding. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods for her kiosk

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en: Myagmarsuren S. is 20 years old and lives with his parents in a house in Arhangai province in the central part of Mongolia. He began his food selling business in 2008 with the help of his parents and with working capital of 2,500,000 MNT. Since then, he has been earning enough money to greatly improve their quality of life. Now his working capital exceeds 4,000,000 MNT. With the business earnings, he is able to afford his university tuition fees. Myagmarsuren is a modest man who is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to help him purchase a large amount of a variety of food.

loans.use: To  purchase inventory

loans.name: Marybell

texts.en:
Marybell F. is from the town of Banga. She is 43 years old and married with 2 school-aged children. She grows ducks to earn a living. She also supports her husband in farming, keeping the fields free of weeds and pests. They both work hard to keep it productive. She also wants to purchase additional ducks to add to her livestock.

Marybell joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marybell has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and now requests her fourth loan, for 12000 PHP, to purchase fertilizer such as manure, more ducks, and duck feed.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, ducks, and duck feed.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: Francisca, D. 48 años, es una madre D. familia muy trabajadora, vive en su casa propia, junto a su esposo y sus 3 hijos. Se dedica a la venta D. comida a 5 cuadras D. su barrio. Todos los días por las mañanas prepara diferentes platos como: pescado frito, chanfainita, arroz con pollo y salsa D. ocopa entre otros potajes criollos, que solicitan sus clientes. Los guisos los prepara en su casa, y el pescado los fríe en el mismo puesto D. venta, que se encuentra ubicado en el mercado más concurrido D. su barrio. Sus clientes acuden a su puesto a partir D. las 10:00 mañana hasta la 1:00 D. la tarD., en donD. son atendidos amablemente.
